questions.text: Identify the finding shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Herpes labialis

Explanation:

  • Herpes labialis, commonly known as cold sores or fever blisters, is a viral infection caused by the herpes simplex virus type 1 (HSV-1).
  • The characteristic presentation of multiple vesicles and crusts clustered on an inflamed base around the lips is indicative of a herpes simplex virus infection. Occurs on the vermillion border of lips.
  • Recurrent outbreaks are common, often triggered by factors such as stress, sun exposure, or fever.

Incorrect Options:

Herpangina (Option B): It typically presents as small, painful ulcers or vesicles on the back of the throat, soft palate, or tonsillar pillars.

Molluscum contagiosum (Option C): It typically presents as small, raised, dome-shaped papules with a central indentation (umbilication). The lesions are usually flesh-colored

Impetigo (Option D): It commonly presents as honey-colored crusts or bullae on an erythematous base.

questions.text: Among the following, which will not present with dermatological manifestations as seen in the image given?
questions.solution:
Correct Option  C - Aspergillus:

  • Aspergillus is commonly associated with respiratory infections, such as allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) and invasive aspergillosis.
  • Aspergillus infections can cause symptoms such as cough, wheezing, and fever. However, they do not commonly present with skin manifestations similar to those seen in dermatophyte infections.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Trichophyton: Trichophyton infections often present with characteristic skin manifestations, including redness, scaling, and itching.

Option B - Microsporum: Microsporum is another genus of dermatophyte fungi that cause fungal infections of the skin, hair, and nails.Microsporum infections also result in characteristic skin manifestations, including raised, red, and scaly patches.

Option D - Epidemophyton: Epidemophyton is not a recognized genus of fungi. It is likely a misspelling or an incorrect term Like the other dermatophytes, Epidermophyton infections commonly present with characteristic skin manifestations.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy had painful sores in the mouth with a rash over the hands along with fever. Which of these is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Coxsackievirus: 

  • Coxsackieviruses are known to cause hand, foot, and mouth disease (HFMD), which presents with painful sores in the mouth, rash on the hands (and feet), and fever. Therefore, it is the most likely causative agent in this case.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Pox virus: Pox viruses, typically do not cause symptoms in the mouth or rash on the hands as described in the case.

Option C - HHV-7: Human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7) is a virus of the herpesvirus familyit is not commonly associated with sores in the mouth or a specific rash on the hands.

Option D - Parvovirus: Parvovirus B19 typically presents with a characteristic rash on the face ("slapped cheek" appearance).

questions.text: Which among the following drug is not used in the treatment of acne vulgaris?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Topical Fluocinolone

Explanation:

  • Fluocinolone is a corticosteroid, which can cause steroid-induced acne (pustular eruptions).
  • Steroids exacerbate acne rather than treat it.

Grades

Lesions

Treatment

Grade I

Non-inflammatory lesions such as open (blackheads) and closed comedones (whiteheads)

Topical retinoids

(Tretinoin, Adapalene)

Grade II

Non-inflammatory lesions (comedones) + inflammatory lesions such as papules and few pustules.

Topical retinoids + Topical antibiotics

Grade III

Multiple inflammatory papules and pustules ± nodules (moderate)

Topical retinoids + Oral antibiotics ± Benzoyl peroxide

Grade IV

Nodules + Cysts

(Most severe form)

Oral retinoids

(Isotretinoin)

questions.text: What is the diagnosis for a 40-year-old woman who experienced fever and joint pain, and subsequently developed a lesion on her nose a few days after taking NSAIDs?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Chikungunya

Explanation:

  • Chikungunya is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes. It is characterized by symptoms such as high fever, joint pain, muscle pain, headache, and rash.
  • The development of pigmentation on the nose after taking NSAIDs can occur in chikungunya. Other symptoms, such as joint pain and fever support this diagnosis.
  • Some other dermatological features associated with chikungunya include:
    • Maculopapular rash: small, raised bumps on the skin. The rash can appear on the trunk, limbs, and face. It is usually non-itchy and may be accompanied by redness or discoloration of the skin.
    • Erythema multiforme-like rash: characterized by target-shaped or iris-like lesions with concentric rings of color on the skin. It typically affects the extremities, including the hands and feet.
    • Vesiculobullous lesions: Rarely, chikungunya can cause the formation of fluid-filled blisters or bullae on the skin.
    • Desquamation: After the initial rash subsides, some individuals with chikungunya may experience desquamation


Incorrect Options:

Dengue (Option A): The rash in dengue is often described as maculopapular or petechial and can appear on the trunk, limbs, and face. The symptoms and rash pattern associated with dengue differ from the presentation described in the question, making it an incorrect option.

Melasma (Option C): Melasma is typically associated with hormonal changes, sun exposure, and genetic factors. The lesions in melasma are symmetrical and do not usually present as a single lesion on the nose as shown in the image. Therefore, melasma is an incorrect option.

Fixed drug eruption (Option D): Fixed drug eruption is a type of drug reaction characterized by recurring skin lesions at the same site each time the causative drug is taken. The lesions typically appear as well-demarcated, round or oval patches with dusky red or violaceous coloration. While fixed drug eruptions can occur after taking certain medications, they are not typically associated with the use of NSAIDs alone.

questions.text: What could be the potential cause of the following lesions in a gardener who has a history of thorn pricks?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Sporothrix schenckii

Explanation:

  • The lesions described in the question, following a thorn prick, are suggestive of a condition known as sporotrichosis or rose gardener's disease.
  • The characteristic feature of sporotrichosis is the distribution of the lesions along the lymphatic vessels. The infection typically starts as a small, painless bump or nodule at the site of the inoculation, and it then spreads along the lymphatic vessels, forming a chain of nodules or ulcers.

Sporotrichosis

  • Sporotrichosis is a chronic fungal infection caused by Sporothrix schenckii, commonly known as “rose gardener’s disease.” It occurs through trauma-induced inoculation from soil, plants, or organic matter.

Pathophysiology

  • Sporothrix schenckii is a dimorphic fungus that exists as a mold in the environment and yeast in human tissue.
  • The fungus spreads via lymphatics, causing characteristic nodular lymphangitis.

Features

  • Cutaneous (most common):
    • Painless nodules and ulcers along lymphatic channels (lymphocutaneous form).
  • Pulmonary:
    • Chronic cough, fever, weight loss (inhalation exposure).
  • Disseminated (rare, immunocompromised patients):
    • Systemic involvement affecting bones, joints, and CNS.

Investigations & Diagnosis

  • Culture (gold standard): Grows Sporothrix schenckii on Sabouraud’s agar.
  • Microscopy: Shows cigar-shaped yeast on tissue samples.
  • Histopathology: Granulomatous inflammation with fungal elements.

Treatment

  • First-line: Itraconazole (100-200 mg/day) for cutaneous cases.
  • Severe/disseminated cases: Amphotericin B, followed by itraconazole.
  • Potassium iodide (older treatment): Still used in some regions.

Incorrect Options:

Streptococcus pyogenes (Option A): It is not the causative agent for the described presentation of lesions following a thorn prick.

Strongyloides stercoralis (Option C): Strongyloides stercoralis does not typically present with the specific lesion distribution described in the question.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option D): Staphylococcus aureus is not the primary causative agent for the described presentation. Sporothrix schenckii is more commonly associated with the development of sporotrichosis in this context.

questions.text: Identify the type of skin lesion:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B - Annular

  • The correct option is "annular." An annular skin lesion refers to a ring-shaped lesion with a clear or normal-looking center. It typically has a raised border or edge. This pattern is commonly seen in conditions such as ringworm (tinea corporis), granuloma annulare, and erythema migrans (associated with Lyme disease).

Some other types of skin lesions:

Skin Lesion

Description

Examples

Macule

Flat, discolored spot on the skin with no palpable elevation or depression.

Freckles, flat moles

Patch

Large, flat, maculopapular area of skin discoloration.

Vitiligo, café-au-lait spots

Papule

Small, solid, elevated lesion with a palpable surface.

Acne, warts

Plaque

Elevated, flat-topped lesion with a broad, flat surface.

Psoriasis plaques, seborrheic keratosis

Vesicle

Small, fluid-filled blister, usually less than 5mm in diameter.

Chickenpox blisters, herpes simplex

Bulla

Large, fluid-filled blister, typically more than 5mm in diameter.

Bullous pemphigoid, second-degree burns

Pustule

Small, elevated lesion filled with pus.

Acne pustules, impetigo

Wheal

Transient, raised, and edematous lesion with irregular borders, often associated with itching or allergic reactions.

Insect bite reactions, hives (urticaria)

Nodule

Solid, palpable lesion, often deeper in the skin layers.

Dermatofibroma, lipoma

Tumor

Solid, elevated lesion larger than a few centimeters in diameter.

Basal cell carcinoma, melanoma

Plaque

Large, flat, elevated lesion with a flat surface and a diameter greater than its height.

Psoriasis plaques, lichen planus

Burrow

Linear or serpignious tunnel in the skin caused by infestation or burrowing of parasites.

Scabies burrows

Scale

Dry, flaky, or thickened skin with shedding of dead skin cells.

Psoriasis scales, seborrheic dermatitis

Crust

Dried exudate or secretion on the skin surface.

Impetigo crusts, dried blood crusts

Erosion

Loss of the superficial epidermis, resulting in a moist, shallow depression.

Aphthous ulcers, erosion due to scratching

Ulcer

Loss of the entire epidermis and at least part of the dermis, resulting in a deep, open lesion.

Pressure ulcers, venous ulcers

Fissure

Linear crack or slit-like split in the skin.

Athlete's foot fissures, anal fissures

Scar

Fibrous tissue that replaces normal skin after injury or surgery.

Surgical scars, keloids

Atrophy

Thinning or depression of the skin with loss of normal skin markings.

Striae (stretch marks), aged skin

Incorrect Options:

Nummular lesions (Option A): These are coin-shaped or circular lesions with distinct borders and a flat or slightly elevated surface. They are usually smaller and do not have the characteristic ring shape.

Discoid lesions (Option C): These are circular or oval-shaped lesions with well-defined borders, but they do not necessarily have a ring shape or central clearing.

Target lesions (Option D): Target or "bull's eye" lesions have concentric rings or circles of different colors. They typically have three zones—an outer ring, an intermediate ring, and a central clearing. This pattern is seen in conditions such as erythema multiforme and Lyme disease.

questions.text: Which of the following options should be excluded as a possible cause for the lesion seen in the image, developed by a forest officer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) KFD

Explanation:

  • The lesion described by a forest officer suggests an eschar-like lesion, which is commonly seen in scrub typhus, cutaneous anthrax, and brown recluse spider bites.
  • KFD (Kyasanur Forest Disease) is a viral hemorrhagic fever caused by a Flavivirus, transmitted by ticks. It primarily affects forest workers but does not cause eschar formation. Instead, it presents with fever, myalgia, haemorrhagic manifestations, and meningoencephalitis.
  • Kyasanur Forest Disease (KFD) is a tick-borne viral disease (Flavivirus) endemic to forests in South India.
  • Transmission: By Haemaphysalis ticks from infected rodents, monkeys, and livestock.

 

Monkey fever/Kyasanur forest disease:

General features:

  • Virus Characteristics: Enveloped virus belonging to the family Flaviviridae; contains single-stranded RNA (ssRNA).
  • Vector: Hard ticks (Haemaphysalis spinigera)
  • Hosts: Monkeys, rodents, and squirrels are common hosts; monkeys act as amplifier hosts where the virus multiplies exponentially.
  • Seasonality: KFD cases peak during dry months (November to June), coinciding with increased human activity in forests.

 

 

The life cycle of Kyasanur forest disease

Clinical features:

  • Incubation Period: 3-8 days.
  • First Stage (Hemorrhagic Fever):
    • Acute high fever with malaise and frontal headaches.
    • Hemorrhagic symptoms: bleeding from the nasal cavity, throat, gums, and gastrointestinal tract.
  • Second Stage: Meningoencephalitis may occur 7–21 days after the first stage.

 

Lab diagnosis:

  • Diagnosis Methods:
    • Virus isolation from blood.
    • IgM antibody detection by ELISA.
    • RT-PCR.

 

Vaccination:

  • Vaccine Type: Killed KFD vaccine (formalin-inactivated chick embryo) developed at Haffkine Institute, Mumbai.
  • Vaccination Schedule:
    • Initial two doses at 2-month intervals.
    • Booster doses at 6–9 months, then every 5 years.
  • Target Area: Recommended for endemic areas of Karnataka.

 

Vector

Diseases transmitted

Sandfly

Kala-azar

Oriental sore

Sandfly fever (Papatasi fever)

Flea

Hymenolepis diminuta

Hymenolepis nana

Bubonic plague

Endemic typhus

Louse

Epidemic relapsing fever

Epidemic typhus

Trench fever

Hard tick

Babesiosis

Kyasanur Forest disease virus (Option B)

Colorado tick fever virus

Russian spring-summer encephalitis virus

Omsk hemorrhagic fever virus

Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever virus

Tularemia

Lyme disease

Rocky Mountain spotted fever

Indian tick typhus

Ehrlichiosis

Soft tick

Endemic relapsing fever

Reduvid bug

Chagas’ disease

 

 

Scrub typhus (Option A) is incorrect because it is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi and commonly presents with an eschar at the site of a chigger bite. This is a hallmark of the disease.

Cutaneous anthrax (Option C) is incorrect because Bacillus anthracis causes painless black eschars with surrounding oedema. It is common in individuals handling animal products or exposed to spores in the environment.

Healing brown recluse spider bite (Option D) is incorrect because brown recluse spider bites can cause necrotic ulcers that heal over time, mimicking an eschar.

questions.text: What is the appropriate next course of action for a child who exhibits itchy scalp lesions and hair loss, as depicted in the image provided?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) KOH mount

 

Explanation:

The image depicts a scaly, inflamed, well-demarcated lesion on the scalp with hair loss, suggestive of Tinea Capitis (scalp ringworm).

KOH (potassium hydroxide) mount is the gold standard for diagnosing superficial fungal infections, including Tinea Capitis, by detecting fungal hyphae in hair shafts and skin scrapings.

 

Tinea Capitis:

  • Caused by: Trichophyton and Microsporum species.
  • Common in children, especially in warm, humid climates.
  • Types:
    • Non-inflammatory: Scaly patches with broken hairs.
    • Inflammatory (Kerion): Painful, boggy swelling with pustules and crusting (as seen in the image).

Diagnosis:

  • KOH Mount: Detects fungal hyphae in hair shafts and skin scrapings.
  • Fungal Culture: Confirms the fungal species.
  • Wood’s Lamp Examination: Fluorescence in Microsporum infections.

Management:

  • Systemic antifungals (Griseofulvin or Terbinafine) for 6–8 weeks (topical antifungals alone are ineffective).
  • Antifungal shampoos (ketoconazole or selenium sulfide) reduce fungal shedding.
  • Kerion cases may need corticosteroids to reduce inflammation.

Slit Skin Mount (Option B) is incorrect because it is used for leprosy diagnosis by identifying acid-fast bacilli from skin lesions, which is not relevant in this case.

Gram Staining (Option C) is incorrect because it is useful for diagnosing bacterial infections (e.g., impetigo, folliculitis) but not fungal infections like Tinea Capitis.

Biopsy (Option D) is incorrect because skin biopsy is rarely needed for diagnosing Tinea Capitis and is usually reserved for atypical or unclear cases.

questions.text: A female patient presented with acne that is not resolving on oral isotretinoin and antibiotics therapy. Which of the following is the next best investigation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Evaluate for hyperandrogenism

Explanation:

  • The patient presents with acne that is not responding to oral isotretinoin and antibiotics, which suggests that a more systemic or hormonal cause could be contributing to the acne.
  • Hyperandrogenism is commonly associated with conditions like polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) and congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), both of which can lead to increased sebum production and hormonal imbalances, exacerbating acne.
  • Evaluating for hyperandrogenism through tests like testosterone levels, dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate (DHEAS), and other hormonal markers is crucial to rule out these underlying causes.
  • Hyperandrogenism is when the body produces too much androgen, a male hormone. This can contribute to the development of acne in women and other symptoms such as hirsutism and irregular periods.
  • Treatment may involve medications such as oral contraceptives or anti-androgen drugs.

 

Look for dietary triggers (Option A): Acne can be affected by diet in some people, particularly those with a high glycemic index or a diet high in dairy products. However, this is typically considered after other causes of acne have been ruled out. Additionally, dietary changes may not be sufficient to treat acne on their own, but rather they can be used in conjunction with other treatments.

Check for antibiotic resistance (Option C): Antibiotics are often used to treat acne, but over time, the bacteria that causes acne can become resistant to the antibiotics. If a patient's acne is not improving with antibiotics, checking for antibiotic resistance can help determine if a different treatment approach is needed.

Look for drug triggers (Option D): Certain medications can contribute to the development of acne. For example, corticosteroids, anticonvulsants, and some hormonal medications can cause acne as a side effect. If a patient takes any medications that may increase the risk of acne, it is important to evaluate their treatment plan and consider alternative medications if necessary.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with the lesion given in the image below. He also mentions experiencing sensations like a spider crawling in the area of the lesion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The image shows a dermatomal distribution of grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, which is characteristic of Herpes zoster (shingles).
  • The patient reports paresthesia ("spider crawling sensation"), a common prodromal symptom due to viral reactivation affecting sensory nerves.
  • The lesion pattern is unilateral, consistent with reactivation of Varicella-zoster virus (VZV) from dorsal root ganglia.

Herpes Zoster:

Feature

Details

Etiology

Reactivation of Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) from latency in sensory ganglia.

Risk Factors

Immunosuppression, aging (>50 years), stress, malignancy, chronic diseases (diabetes).

Clinical Features

Painful, grouped vesicles on an erythematous base along a single dermatome (usually thoracic, lumbar, or trigeminal).

Prodromal Symptoms

Burning, tingling, paresthesia ("spider crawling sensation"), fever, malaise before rash appears.

Complications

Postherpetic neuralgia (PHN), bacterial superinfection, ophthalmic zoster (if V1 of trigeminal nerve is involved).

Diagnosis

Clinical; Tzanck smear (multinucleated giant cells), PCR for VZV in doubtful cases.

Treatment

Antiviral therapy (acyclovir, valacyclovir, famciclovir) within 72 hours, analgesics, corticosteroids (if severe pain).

Prevention

Zoster vaccine for elderly and immunocompromised individuals.

 

Irritant contact dermatitis (Option B) is incorrect because it results from direct skin damage due to chemical exposure, leading to erythema, scaling, and burning, rather than a vesicular dermatomal rash with neuropathic pain.

 

Allergic contact dermatitis (Option C) is incorrect because it is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction (Type IV), presenting as itchy, erythematous, and vesicular plaques in areas of contact, but lacks dermatomal distribution and prodromal neuralgia.

 

Herpes simplex infection (Option D) is incorrect because HSV causes grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, but these typically appear around the mouth (HSV-1) or genital region (HSV-2) and do not follow a dermatomal pattern.

questions.text: What could be the potential diagnosis for a 7-year-old boy with intellectual disability who has developed extensive warty crusts on the trunk, hands, and feet, along with severe fissuring and scaling on the soles of his feet?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Norwegian scabies

Explanation:

  • Norwegian scabies (crusted scabies) is a severe, highly contagious form of scabies, seen in immunocompromised individuals, elderly patients, or those with neurological disorders (e.g., intellectual disability).

Feature

Classic Scabies

Crusted (Norwegian) Scabies

Prevalence

More common

Less common

Skin Lesions

Small erythematous papules, "knots on a rope"

Erythematous, scaling, crusting, and fissuring

Pruritus

Severe, worse at night

Usually mild or absent due to nerve damage

Onset

3-6 weeks after initial colonization, 1-3 days after reinfestation

Gradual but progressive

Risk Factors

No specific immunosuppression required

Occurs in immunosuppressed patients (HIV, elderly, cancer, etc.)

Mite Burden

Low mite burden

High mite burden

Transmission

Direct skin-to-skin contact

More commonly transmitted via fomites (objects)

Common Sites

Webs of fingers, axillae, areola, genitalia

Hands, feet, and scalp

 

Incorrect Options:

Scabies incognito (Option A):

  • Occurs due to misuse of topical steroids, modifying typical scabies lesions.
  • Presents as diffuse eczema-like plaques rather than thick crusts.

Animal scabies (Option B): It is usually seen in animals and is rarely transmitted to humans

Nodular scabies (Option C): a less common form of scabies that causes firm, itchy, red bumps. It's often found in the groin and genital area.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Impetigo

Explanation:

  • The image shows honey-colored, crusted lesions around the mouth, characteristic of non-bullous impetigo.
  • Impetigo is a superficial bacterial skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes.
  • Common in children and spreads via direct contact.

Impetigo

Feature

Details

Etiology

Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes

Types

Non-bullous (crusted), Bullous

Lesion

Honey-colored crusts, vesicles, erosions

Common Sites

Face (perioral, perinasal), extremities

Treatment

Topical mupirocin, oral antibiotics if extensive

Bullous impetigo

Non-bullous impetigo/Impetigo contagiosa

Incorrect Options:

Chickenpox (Option B) - Incorrect because vesicles appear in crops and have a dew-drop on a rose petal appearance, unlike the honey-colored crusts seen in impetigo.

Herpes Simplex (Option C) - Incorrect because it presents as grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, often with pain and recurrence, whereas impetigo shows crusted lesions.

Molluscum Contagiosum (Option D) - Incorrect because it presents as pearly, dome-shaped papules with central umbilication, not crusted erosions.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a farmer who has a swollen foot and multiple discharging sinuses, as depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Mycetoma

Explanation:

  • The most probable diagnosis for a farmer with a swollen foot and multiple discharging sinuses is Mycetoma

Mycetoma (Madura Foot)

  • Definition: Chronic granulomatous infection with subcutaneous masses, draining sinuses, and grains in exudates
  • Types:
    • Eumycetoma (fungal)
    • Actinomycetoma (bacterial)

Clinical Presentation

  • Initial Lesion:
    • Painless nodule; may be asymptomatic for years
  • Progression:
    • Leads to swelling, ulceration, and pus discharge from sinuses containing grains
  • Complications:
    • Severe deformities, osteomyelitis, potential amputation due to extensive tissue damage

 

Microscopic Examination

Type

Causative Agents

Microscopic Features

Eumycetoma

Madurella mycetomatis, Curvularia lunata, Scedosporium spp., Acremonium spp.
  • Hyphae or thick-walled grains (black/white).
  • Histology shows suppurative granulomas with neutrophils.

Actinomycetoma

Actinomadura madurae, Nocardia spp.

Thin, branching filaments visible with Gram staining. Similar granulomas to eumycetoma but distinct morphology.

 

Diagnostic Techniques

  • Biopsy and Culture:
    • Tissue biopsy for visualization of pathogens.
    • Culturing exudates for specific organism identification.
    • Special stains to differentiate fungal and bacterial infections.
  • Imaging Studies:
    • X-rays and MRI to assess bone involvement in advanced cases.

Treatment

Type

Treatment Approach

Eumycetoma

Surgical excision with antifungals (itraconazole, ketoconazole). High recurrence rates.

Actinomycetoma

Prolonged antibiotic therapy (e.g., trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, dapsone) along with surgical intervention.

 

Squamous Cell Carcinoma (SCC) (Option B):

  • SCC can develop in chronic ulcers or scars but is not characterized by multiple discharging sinuses with granules.

Nocardia (Option C):

  • While Nocardia can cause actinomycetoma, which is a type of mycetoma, Nocardia alone does not fully describe the condition seen in the image.
  • The term mycetoma broadly refers to both eumycetoma (fungal) and actinomycetoma (bacterial), including those caused by Nocardia.

Sporotrichosis (Option D):

  • A subcutaneous fungal infection (Sporothrix schenckii) that spreads along lymphatics (sporotrichoid spread) but does not present with multiple sinus tracts and granules.

questions.text: A 45 year old male patient from Bihar presented with normoanesthetic hypopigmented lesion as shown below. He had a history of fever for a long duration in his childhood. No thickened nerves were present. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: D) Post kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis

 

Explanation:

The patient is from Bihar, an endemic region for visceral leishmaniasis (kala-azar).

The image shows multiple hypopigmented macules over the back, characteristic of PKDL.

History of prolonged fever in childhood suggests prior kala-azar infection, which is a prerequisite for developing PKDL.

No thickened nerves rule out leprosy.

 

Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL):

  • PKDL is a chronic dermal complication of visceral leishmaniasis caused by Leishmania donovani.
  • Endemic in India, Nepal, and Sudan, especially in Bihar, West Bengal, and Uttar Pradesh.

Clinical Features:

  • Occurs months to years after treated visceral leishmaniasis.
  • Hypopigmented macules, erythematous papules, or nodules on the face, trunk, and extremities.
  • No loss of sensation or thickened nerves (differentiating from leprosy).
  • Histopathology: Presence of Leishman-Donovan (LD) bodies.

Diagnosis:

  • Slit-skin smear or skin biopsy showing Leishmania donovani bodies.
  • PCR or rK39 serology can confirm diagnosis.

Management:

  • First-line treatment: Miltefosine for 12 weeks.
  • Alternatives: Liposomal amphotericin B or paromomycin.

Tuberculoid leprosy (Option A) is incorrect because it presents with single or few hypopigmented macules with loss of sensation. Thickened peripheral nerves are a hallmark feature, which is absent in this case.

Lepromatous leprosy (Option B) is incorrect because it presents with multiple ill-defined hypopigmented macules with symmetric distribution. Thickened nerves and sensation loss are typical, but they are absent in this patient.

Mycosis fungoides (Option C) is incorrect because it presents as erythematous scaly plaques rather than hypopigmented macules. It is a form of cutaneous T-cell lymphoma, which is not related to prior fever or endemic infections.

questions.text: What is the probable diagnosis for a young man who has presented with painful lesions depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct answer: A) Herpes Zoster

 

Explanation:

The image shows a unilateral, dermatomal eruption of grouped vesicles on an erythematous base. The patient has painful lesions, which is a key feature of Herpes Zoster (Shingles). The lesions appear in a band-like distribution, following the sensory nerve dermatome.

 

Herpes Zoster (Shingles):

  • Cause: Reactivation of Varicella-Zoster Virus (VZV) in the dorsal root ganglion.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Immunosuppression (HIV, malignancies)
    • Elderly individuals
    • Stress and trauma
  • Clinical Features:
    • Painful, grouped vesicles on an erythematous base in a unilateral dermatomal pattern.
    • Pre-eruptive phase (burning, tingling pain) 48–72 hours before rash onset.
    • Thoracic dermatomes are most commonly involved.
    • Postherpetic neuralgia (persistent pain after healing) may develop in older adults.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical, confirmed by Tzanck smear (multinucleated giant cells) or PCR for VZV DNA.
  • Treatment:
    • Antiviral therapy (Acyclovir, Valacyclovir) within 72 hours of rash onset.
    • Analgesics for pain control.
    • Corticosteroids in severe cases.

Molluscum Contagiosum (Option B) is incorrect because Molluscum contagiosum presents as small, umbilicated, pearly white papules, not as vesicular eruptions. It is usually asymptomatic and not painful.

Herpes Simplex (Option C) is incorrect because Herpes simplex virus (HSV) causes clusters of vesicles but does not usually follow a dermatomal distribution. HSV infections typically affect the oral (HSV-1) or genital (HSV-2) regions rather than the thoracic dermatomes.

Lymphangioma Circumscriptum (Option D) is incorrect because lymphangioma circumscriptum is a benign lymphatic malformation, presenting as clusters of small, translucent vesicles ("frog spawn" appearance). It is not painful and does not appear in a dermatomal pattern.

questions.text: Which of the following does not present with maculopapular rash?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Zoster (shingles):

  • Zoster (shingles) - Zoster is characterized by a painful rash that typically develops into fluid-filled blisters.
  • The rash follows a dermatomal distribution, typically appearing as a band or stripe on one side of the body. It is not typically maculopapular in nature.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Rubella:  Rubella, also known as German measles, presents with a maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads to the rest of the body.

Option C - Dengue: During the febrile phase of dengue, a maculopapular rash may be present.

Option D - Measles: Measles, also known as rubeola, presents with a characteristic maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads to the rest of the body.

questions.text: What is incorrect regarding the displayed lesion?

choices.text: The lesions are infectious to seronegative individuals
Geniculate ganglion is involved in Ramsay Hunt syndrome

questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Bilaterally symmetrical dermatomal vesicular eruption:

  • Bilaterally symmetrical dermatomal vesicular eruption : This statement is incorrect.
  • The lesions shown are likely caused by a viral infection, such as herpes zoster (shingles).
  • The lesions shown are typically unilateral (on one side of the body) and follow a dermatomal distribution. A dermatome is an area of skin supplied by a single spinal nerve. Therefore, the eruption is usually unilateral, not bilaterally symmetrical.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The lesions are infectious to seronegative individuals: This statement is correct.. These viral lesions can be infectious and can spread to seronegative (non-immune) individuals.

Option B - Can be associated with meningoencephalitis: This statement is correct. The lesion shown, particularly if it involves the cranial nerves, can be associated with meningoencephalitis,

Option D - Geniculate ganglion is involved in Ramsay Hunt syndrome: This statement is correct.The geniculate ganglion, which is part of the facial nerve, is involved in this syndrome.

questions.text: What will be the diagnosis of an infant exhibiting the following condition, after a pharyngeal infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome:

  • Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS): This is the correct option.
  • SSSS is a bacterial skin infection caused by Staphylococcus aureus.
  • It typically affects infants and young children, especially those with weakened immune systems.
  • The condition is characterized by widespread erythema (redness) of the skin, followed by the development of large fluid-filled blisters that resemble scalded skin.
  • These blisters are fragile and can easily rupture, leaving behind raw, denuded skin.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option B - Epidermolysis bullosa simplex: This is an incorrect option. Epidermolysis bullosa simplex is a genetic disorder characterized by the presence of fragile skin that is prone to blistering. The condition is not specifically associated with pharyngeal infections.

Option C - Impetigo contagiosa: It is characterized by the development of small, fluid-filled blisters that eventually burst, leaving behind honey-colored crusts.

Option D - Pemphigus foliaceus: This is an incorrect option. Pemphigus foliaceus is an autoimmune blistering disorder characterized by the presence of superficial blisters on the skin and mucous membranes

questions.text: The Lesions shown below are the characteristic of :
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Molluscum contagiosum

 

Explanation:

 

The lesions described as small, dome-shaped, flesh-colored or pearly papules with a central umbilication are classically seen in Molluscum Contagiosum, a viral skin infection caused by a poxvirus.

Feature Description
Lesion appearance Smooth, dome-shaped papules with central dimple
Colour Flesh-colored, pink, or pearly-white
Size Typically 2–5 mm in diameter
Common in Children, sexually active adults, immunocompromised
Location Face, trunk, axillae, genital area
Cause Molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV, a poxvirus)

 

Chicken pox (Option B): Lesions are vesicular, appear in crops, and progress from papules to vesicles to crusts — not dome-shaped papules.

 

Pemphigus (Option C): Autoimmune blistering disorder — presents with flaccid bullae and erosions, not pearly papules.

 

Common warts (Option D): Caused by HPV — lesions are verrucous, rough, and hyperkeratotic, not smooth or dome-shaped.

questions.text: What is the most frequently encountered cause of the condition shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Infection:

  • In the case of erythema multiforme, the most common triggering factor is infection.
  • Erythema multiforme is a skin condition characterized by target-like lesions, typically affecting the extremities, mucous membranes, and sometimes the trunk.
  • It is believed to be an immune-mediated reaction triggered by various factors, with infection being the most common cause.
  • Infection, especially viral infections like herpes simplex virus, is the most common triggering factor for erythema multiforme.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Vaccination: It is not a common triggering factor..

Option B - Malignancy: It is not a primary triggering factor for erythema multiforme.

Option C - Drugs: Drugs can indeed trigger erythema multiforme in some cases, particularly certain medications like nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), antibiotics (such as sulfonamides and penicillins), and antiepileptic drugs. However, infection remains the most common triggering factor.

questions.text: What is the accurate statement regarding the diagnosis made from the provided image?

choices.text: Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected
Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved
Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved:

  • Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved: In herpes zoster, the involvement of mucous membranes within the affected dermatome is possible.
  • If the dermatome affected by herpes zoster includes mucous membranes, such as the oral or genital mucosa, these areas can develop characteristic vesicles and ulcers

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - The lesions are not infectious: The presence of painful grouped vesicles in a single dermatome, as seen in the image, is highly suggestive of herpes zoster, which is an infectious viral condition..

Option B - Trigeminal dermatome is most commonly affected: Herpes zoster can affect dermatomes in decreasing order of frequency thoracic > cervical > Trigeminal > lumbosacral.

Option C - Anterior nerve roots are more commonly involved: In herpes zoster, it is the posterior nerve roots or ganglia that are typically affected by the reactivated varicella-zoster virus.

questions.text: What will be the diagnosis of the image provided below?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Candidal intertrigo:

  • Candidal intertrigo: This condition refers to a fungal infection that occurs in moist skin folds, such as between the toes, groin, or fingers.
  • It is characterized by redness, itching, and maceration of the affected area. The image shows candidal intertrigo between the small finger of the foot, which matches the clinical presentation.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Candidal paronychia: This condition refers to a fungal infection that affects the nail folds and surrounding tissues

Option B - Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome: This is a bacterial infection caused by certain strains of Staphylococcus aureus. It typically presents with widespread redness, blistering, and peeling of the skin.

Option D - Diabetic foot ulcer: This term refers to a non-healing ulcer that develops in individuals with diabetes, typically on the feet. It is often associated with poor circulation and neuropathy.

questions.text: Which organism is typically responsible for causing verruca vulgaris?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Human papillomavirus – 2:

  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) - 2: Verruca vulgaris, also known as common warts, is primarily caused by infection with human papillomavirus (HPV) types 2 and 4.
  • HPV is a DNA virus that infects the skin and mucous membranes.
  • HPV type 2 is specifically associated with the development of verruca vulgaris.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - HPV-1: Human papillomavirus type 1 is primarily associated with the development of plantar warts (verruca plantaris) rather than verruca vulgaris.

Option B - HPV-3: Human papillomavirus type 3 is commonly associated with epidermodysplasia verruciformis, a rare genetic disorder characterized by multiple wart-like skin lesions.

Option C - HPV-10:  Human papillomavirus type 10 is not typically associated with verruca vulgaris. It is more commonly linked to flat warts (verruca plana) or other types of cutaneous warts.

questions.text: Varicella – zoster virus remains dormant in the:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Dorsal root ganglion:

  • Dorsal root ganglion: Varicella-zoster virus (VZV), the virus responsible for chickenpox and shingles, remains dormant (latent) in the sensory neurons of the dorsal root ganglia.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Medulla oblongata: The medulla oblongata is not a site where the varicella-zoster virus remains dormant.

Option C - Skin: The varicella-zoster does not remain dormant in the skin.

Option D - Ventral root: The ventral root of the spinal nerve contains motor fibers and is not involved in the latency or reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus.

questions.text: Which drug, known for developing widespread resistance, is commonly used in the treatment of Tinea cruris?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C -Terbinafine:

  • The correct answer is Terbinafine. Terbinafine is a drug commonly used in the treatment of Tinea cruris, also known as jock itch.
  • However, widespread resistance is being observed with this drug, making it less effective in some cases.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Itraconazole: There is no widespread resistance reported for itraconazole in the treatment of Tinea cruris.

Option B - Griseofulvin: While some cases of resistance have been reported, it is not as widespread as the resistance observed with terbinafine.

Option D - Voriconazole: It is not commonly used for Tinea cruris. Although resistance to voriconazole can occur, it is not specifically associated with the treatment of Tinea cruris.
